Before 9/11, the 
      government's "No Fly List" had 16 suspected terrorists on it.  Five 
      years later, the list ballooned to 44,000 and had become riddled with 
      inaccuracies, including dead people and international leaders not likely 
      to commit acts of terror. In our lead story, correspondent Steve Kroft takes 
      another look at the list and shows that, despite deletions like the 
      president of Bolivia 
      and the speaker of the Lebanese Parliament, flying can still be a hassle 
      for thousands of people, especially if you have a common name shared 
      by thousands – like Robert Johnson, Gary Smith or John 
      Williams.
 
Watch an 
      excerpt.
 
Speaking of names, Barry 
      Diller is one you may not have heard in a while, but his recent 
      accomplishments are too big to miss.  In Hollywood, he was 
      responsible for movies like "Urban Cowboy," "Raiders of the Lost Ark" and 
      "Beverly Hills Cop." Then he started the fourth television network, 
      Fox.  In his third act, the home shopping giants QVC and HSN 
      flourished under his hand. What’s Diller up to now? Combining brands like 
      Ticketmaster and Match.com, he’s formed InterActive Corp., which Fortune 
      magazine named America’s most admired company 
      in Internet services. What does this billionaire do for an encore? He 
      marries the beautiful, rich clothing designer Diane von Furstenberg. Correspondent Lesley Stahl 
      reports.
 
Watch Stahl's reporter's 
      notebook.
 
In our third story, correspondent Bob Simon takes you 
      to an exotic place where the people and the lifestyle will open your eyes 
      in wonder. The Moken people of the Andaman Sea in Southeast 
      Asia have no words in their language for time.  Nor do 
      they bid one another hello or goodbye. There is no word for "want." 
      They've lived a nomadic life on the sea, living on their boats and on 
      tropical islands, living for and in the moment, for hundreds of 
      years.  So as the seas receded from their islands before the deadly 
      tsunami of Christmas 2004, they knew to run for high ground and saved 
      themselves. Saleh Kalathalay, an elder Moken, explained to Simon what 
      happened. "The wave is created by the spirit of the sea. The big wave had 
      not eaten anyone for a long time and it wanted to taste them 
      again."
